2.1 ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏•‡∏∞‡πÇ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏û‡πá‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏à

# ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏î‡∏ï‡∏±‡πâ‡∏á‡πÅ‡∏û‡πá‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏à‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏à‡∏≥‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô
# install.packages(c("brms", "rstanarm", "tidyverse", "bayesplot"))

# ‡πÇ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏î‡πÅ‡∏û‡πá‡∏Å‡πÄ‡∏Å‡∏à
library(brms)
library(rstanarm)
library(tidyverse)
library(bayesplot)



2.2 ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•
‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏µ‡∏¢‡∏°‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏î‡∏µ‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏û‡∏∑‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏Ñ‡∏±‡∏ç‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏´‡πå ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏£‡∏ó‡∏≥‡∏ï‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≠‡πÑ‡∏õ‡∏ô‡∏µ‡πâ:

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏≥‡∏•‡∏≠‡∏á‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏î‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏£‡∏Ñ‡πÑ‡∏´‡∏°‡πâ‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏ß
set.seed(123) # ‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå‡∏Ñ‡∏á‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà

# ‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î‡∏à‡∏≥‡∏ô‡∏ß‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á
n <- 200

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏™‡∏†‡∏≤‡∏û‡πÅ‡∏ß‡∏î‡∏•‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°
temperature <- rnorm(n, mean = 28, sd = 3)  # ‡∏≠‡∏∏‡∏ì‡∏´‡∏†‡∏π‡∏°‡∏¥ (¬∞C)
humidity <- rnorm(n, mean = 85, sd = 8)     # ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏ä‡∏∑‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏±‡∏°‡∏û‡∏±‡∏ó‡∏ò‡πå (%)
rainfall <- rgamma(n, shape = 2, scale = 10) # ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏ì‡∏ô‡πâ‡∏≥‡∏ù‡∏ô (‡∏°‡∏°./‡∏ß‡∏±‡∏ô)
wind_speed <- rnorm(n, mean = 5, sd = 2)    # ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏£‡πá‡∏ß‡∏•‡∏° (‡∏Å‡∏°./‡∏ä‡∏°.)

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏à‡∏±‡∏î‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£
variety <- sample(c("‡∏™‡∏∏‡∏û‡∏£‡∏£‡∏ì‡∏ö‡∏∏‡∏£‡∏µ 1", "‡∏õ‡∏ó‡∏∏‡∏°‡∏ò‡∏≤‡∏ô‡∏µ 1", "‡∏Å‡∏Ç49", "‡∏Å‡∏Ç61"), n, replace = TRUE)
planting_density <- rnorm(n, mean = 25, sd = 3) # ‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏¢‡∏∞‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏π‡∏Å (‡∏ã‡∏°.)
nitrogen_rate <- rnorm(n, mean = 100, sd = 20)  # ‡∏≠‡∏±‡∏ï‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏õ‡∏∏‡πã‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏ô‡πÇ‡∏ï‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏ô (‡∏Å‡∏Å./‡πÑ‡∏£‡πà)

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏™‡∏±‡∏°‡∏û‡∏±‡∏ô‡∏ò‡πå‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏ã‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏ã‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏£‡∏Ñ
# ‡πÇ‡∏î‡∏¢‡∏Ñ‡∏≥‡∏ô‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏ñ‡∏∂‡∏á‡∏õ‡∏±‡∏à‡∏à‡∏±‡∏¢‡∏´‡∏•‡∏±‡∏Å‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡∏°‡∏µ‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏ï‡πà‡∏≠‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏î
logit_severity <- -2 + 
                  0.3 * scale(temperature) +
                  0.4 * scale(humidity) +
                  0.2 * scale(rainfall) +
                  0.1 * scale(wind_speed) +
                  rnorm(n, 0, 0.5)  # ‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏õ‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏ô‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÑ‡∏°‡πà‡∏™‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ñ‡∏≠‡∏ò‡∏¥‡∏ö‡∏≤‡∏¢‡πÑ‡∏î‡πâ

# ‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏á‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡πÄ‡∏õ‡∏≠‡∏£‡πå‡πÄ‡∏ã‡πá‡∏ô‡∏ï‡πå‡∏Ñ‡∏ß‡∏≤‡∏°‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏ô‡πÅ‡∏£‡∏á‡∏Ç‡∏≠‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏£‡∏Ñ
disease_severity <- plogis(logit_severity) * 100

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á data frame
rice_blast_data <- data.frame(
  date = seq(as.Date("2024-01-01"), by = "day", length.out = n),
  plot_id = 1:n,
  temperature = temperature,
  humidity = humidity,
  rainfall = rainfall,
  wind_speed = wind_speed,
  variety = variety,
  planting_density = planting_density,
  nitrogen_rate = nitrogen_rate,
  disease_severity = disease_severity
)

# ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏° missing values ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏∑‡πà‡∏≠‡πÉ‡∏´‡πâ‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏á
set.seed(456)
missing_indices <- sample(1:n, size = n * 0.1)  # 10% missing values
rice_blast_data$disease_severity[missing_indices] <- NA

# ‡πÄ‡∏û‡∏¥‡πà‡∏°‡∏Ñ‡∏≠‡∏•‡∏±‡∏°‡∏ô‡πå‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö‡∏£‡∏∞‡∏¢‡∏∞‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏à‡∏£‡∏¥‡∏ç‡πÄ‡∏ï‡∏¥‡∏ö‡πÇ‡∏ï
rice_blast_data$growth_stage <- cut(
  as.numeric(rice_blast_data$date - min(rice_blast_data$date)),
  breaks = c(-Inf, 30, 60, 90, Inf),
  labels = c("Vegetative", "Tillering", "Booting", "Heading")
)

# ‡πÅ‡∏™‡∏î‡∏á‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏•

title: Implementing Bayesian Models in R for Plant Disease Epidemiology with R
text:
3. ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏• Bayesian

3.1 ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î Prior
‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÄ‡∏•‡∏∑‡∏≠‡∏Å prior ‡∏ó‡∏µ‡πà‡πÄ‡∏´‡∏°‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏™‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏õ‡πá‡∏ô‡∏Ç‡∏±‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ï‡∏≠‡∏ô‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏Ñ‡∏±‡∏ç‡πÉ‡∏ô‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏´‡πå‡πÅ‡∏ö‡∏ö Bayesian:

# ‡∏Å‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏ô‡∏î prior ‡∏™‡∏≥‡∏´‡∏£‡∏±‡∏ö regression coefficients
priors <- c(
prior(normal(0, 2), class = "Intercept"),
prior(normal(0, 1), class = "b"),
prior(student_t(3, 0, 2), class = "sigma")
)

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡πâ‡∏≤‡∏á‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•‡∏û‡∏∑‡πâ‡∏ô‡∏ê‡∏≤‡∏ô
model_disease <- brm(
disease_severity ~ temperature + humidity + rainfall,
data = rice_blast_data,
family = gaussian(),
prior = priors,
chains = 4,
iter = 4000,
warmup = 1000
)

title: Implementing Bayesian Models in R for Plant Disease Epidemiology with R
text:
4. ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡∏ß‡∏¥‡πÄ‡∏Ñ‡∏£‡∏≤‡∏∞‡∏´‡πå‡∏ú‡∏•‡∏•‡∏±‡∏û‡∏ò‡πå

4.1 ‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÅ‡∏õ‡∏•‡∏ú‡∏•‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•

# ‡∏™‡∏£‡∏∏‡∏õ‡∏ú‡∏•‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•
summary(model_disease)

 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = identity 
Formula: disease_severity ~ temperature + humidity + rainfall 
   Data: rice_blast_data (Number of observations: 180) 
  Draws: 4 chains, each with iter = 4000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup draws = 12000

Regression Coefficients:
            Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
Intercept     -75.94      7.15   -90.02   -61.87 1.00    13839     9487
temperature     1.31      0.17     0.98     1.64 1.00    13972     9348
humidity        0.56      0.06     0.44     0.69 1.00    14057     9062
rainfall        0.22      0.04     0.14     0.31 1.00    13011     9232

Further Distributional Parameters:
      Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS
sigma     6.57      0.36     5.91     7.31 1.00    13482     9350

Draws were sampled using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Bulk_ESS
and Tail_ESS are effective sample size measures, and Rhat is the potential
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).

bayes_model <- brm(
  mpg ~ hp,
  data = mtcars,
  family = gaussian(),
  prior = set_prior("normal(0, 10)", class = "b"),
  chains = 4,
  iter = 2000,
  warmup = 1000,
  seed = 1234
)

title: Introduction to Bayesian Statistics in R
Introduction to Bayesian Statistics in R

‡∏ï‡∏±‡∏ß‡∏≠‡∏¢‡πà‡∏≤‡∏á‡∏Å‡∏≤‡∏£‡πÉ‡∏ä‡πâ‡∏á‡∏≤‡∏ô

1. ‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏• Bayesian Linear Regression

library(brms)  
# ‡πÇ‡∏´‡∏•‡∏î‡∏Ç‡πâ‡∏≠‡∏°‡∏π‡∏• mtca
data(mtcars) 
# ‡πÇ‡∏°‡πÄ‡∏î‡∏•: mpg~ hp 
bayes_model <- brm(
  mpg ~ hp,
  data = mtcars,
  family = gaussian(),
  prior = set_prior("normal(0, 10)", class = "b"),
  iter = 4000,
  chains = 4,
  cores = 4
)

Ever feel like you need a pick-me-up while learning stats or a new R tool? Look no further than Allison Horst‚Äôs Data Science Illustrations, featuring the cutest and most educational fuzzy monsters you‚Äôll ever see!

title: R here
text:
data science communities
While these groups are primarily based in SoCal/Santa Barbara, there are tons of awesome groups like these all over the world. Google around to see what‚Äôs near you!

R-Ladies Santa Barbara and R-Ladies Global, which work to promote gender diversity in the R community
EcoDataScience, an environmental data science study group at UCSB

Southern California R Users, an alliance of R user groups in Southern California

Santa Barbara Women in STEM, while not specifically data science-focused, this group holds some really great career and networking events, panels, flash talks, and more

title: R here

web accessibility

The A11Y Project is a community-driven effort to make digital content more accessible. I still have a long way to go in making my own website WCAG compliant ‚Äì the A11Y Project not only has a ton of great blog posts, but also WCAG compliance checklist that I will definitely be returning to over and over again.
Coblis, a color blindness simulator ‚Äì just upload a file and view your color palettes as they would appear under different types of color deficiencies
